ratings.comment: The class structure is being experimented with and likely will continue to be; there are definitely organizational issues that are frustrating. Much of the negative feedback isn't deserved, though. The rationale for many choices are good, and Tyler truly cares about students and making the class actually useful. Also a strong lecturer IMO.

In lectures, Tyler talks as if he is a professional auctioneer and it is impossible to keep up with everything he is saying. The course covers so many topics that reviewing for the 5 different exams takes a very long time. There are in person grades worth 10% each and they reuse questions for both lectures so the second lecture has a big advantage.

Tyler is smart, but the course design is rough: two 30-minute quizzes at 10% each, no past quizzes, and has a drawing section that's 5% of the total grade. The project is also way too long (~12+ hours for each) for just 3%. It's so hard you'll likely use AI to finish and end up know nothing. Please reconsider taking it.

Lectures move far too quickly, with excessive time wasted on demos instead of clear explanations. Projects are overly difficult compared to what's taught and lack proper guidance. The in-person quizzes are unfair since both lectures get the same version, giving later students an advantage and creating unequal testing conditions.
I really enjoyed Tyler's class and learned a lot. People complain too much.
Seems like he's so determined to stick to all these changes despite students' advice

Students are upset with grading for fall 2025, but class is relatively easier compared to other 500 level classes. lets us use AI for projects and exams are very similar to old exams and lectures. Just stay on top of your projects each week rather than waiting till the day before and getting frustated. great prof, and there's 4% EXTRA CREDIT

5 Exams 
WOAT-Worst Of All TIME
Worst Class Ever
Good luck with him from this semester!

I would strongly recommend that you consider the workload of other courses since we don't even have one heavy course. Decide to take this course because of good comments, but add more exams. He seems to fix projects at the beginning of the semester, so lots of bug and update. He should test his course during the summer, including bugs and workload

Since Fall 2025, two in-person quizzes are added and each of them is account for 10% of the final grade. What is worse is that there are writing sections that require you to draw out some diagrams shown in the lecture. The questions are really confusing, but Tyler just don't tell you what they mean. Projects only count for 24% of the grade LMAO :(

Since 2025 Fall, I can say this is the POOEREST CS course that I have taken in my life. 5 exams, many projects with infinite revisions of autograder. Chaos lectures, automatical 1.5x speed. Creating new questions on exam without prior experience and examples. Don't want students successed. A good person, but a unsuccessful teacher

I felt that the class tried to cover too much material, and at times it felt a bit unorganized. It would have been more effective if the content was structured more clearly, rather than touching on many disconnected topics. That said, Tyler was a very good professor and did a great job teaching the material.

The class might be useful. The good things are mentioned by other comments. To me, it tries to cover too many things and Tyler did not make sense of much of them during the class. As someone without much system background, it is easy to get confused. I would still recommend it because of the skill you learned. But his lecture can be confusing.

Great intro course for undergrads. The course has a nice balance between theoretical and practical knowledge. Can't thank more for Tyler preparing hundreds of flashcards for reviewing. He also provides constant and sufficient help for your personal projects outside the course. Tyler is an absolute rare-find.

One of the most organized and communicative professors Ive had. Very knowledgeable about Big Data fundamentals and industry practices. Very supportive of students using content for their own projects. Lectures are not extremely engaging but are clear and organized. Lectures recorded but attendance tracked with tophat. Grades curved. Really caring

Tyler is extremely knowledgeable on the topics he teaches and is always willing to take more time to explain things outside of lecture. His way of helping on projects is unique in that he tries to guide students to debugging themselves instead of just telling them which has helped me learn the material better. Well organized lectures with examples.

Super-smart himself, not good at teaching.

His lecture is pretty good but not helpful for any homework. He always give extra reading such as python documentation and tend to be like "be up to you."

Tyler is probably the best professor I have had. He teaches concepts well and is extremely knowledgeable. He is always willing and eager to answer questions whether it be about the class or beyond. He is also caring for his students and makes it clear that he wants us to succeed.

Best instructor ever. Supportive and caring to students' mental health. His course was supportive and the most organized compared to other CS courses. The course website has a lot of materials for study and he will upload recordings of every lecture to the website. In terms of the project being hard, he would do a demo in the lecture and upload it.
